text:
That's good to hear Nana, doing everything in the beginning is good to realize what you enjoy doing the most :smiley:
I am currently working on Fantastic Beasts: The Crimes of Grindelwald, helping out with a few shots here and there. And strength's and weaknesses for me right now are more technical things, personally I feel like still have a long way to go to become a great Animator, especially in regards to timing and spacing. It's something I'm working towards improving over the next year. 
My greatest strength, I feel, is perseverance. Because I know that if I'm struggling with a shot or I hit a wall, I'll find a way to get through it, and improve myself as an artist. I know how corny that sounds but perseverance is stronger than talent by a long shot.
What do you enjoy the most about making your games Nana?
I enjoy the animating and coding the mostly. Animation because I love giving characters personality and coding because I enjoy the maths side of it.

That's one of the things I love about animation too, and it's cool that you enjoy math, coding is a great skill to have!
Well let me throwback the question you gave me, what do you feel are your strength's and weaknesses at the moment? When you're making a game what do you struggle with the most?
At the moment, my big strength would be my perseverance, but my weakness would be I still have some gaps in my knowledge.

That's good, with perseverance you can overcome those gaps. Let me follow up with another question, what are the gaps you feel you have right now? The more specific and detailed you are the better I can understand how to help you bridge those gaps, ok?
I can't make models(despite me being a decent animator), as well as the fact I don't really under VFX's systems.
I also have a lot ideas, but I am not sure how to put them into a game design document.

I see, what do you mean by "VFX systems"? Like particles and effects?
In regards to ideas, that's always the hardest part. I have a few recommendations I can make if you don't already know them.

This youtube channel is amazing in how you can analyze and breakdown design decisions with popular games, you can learn a lot from each video. <https://www.youtube.com/channel/UCqJ-Xo29CKyLTjn6z2XwYAw> (he also has game jams that you should definitely jump on)

The Art of Game Design by Jesse Schell is good for understanding some philosophies of game design, it's not a technical "how to" book, but more exploratory of ideas.
Rules of Play by Katie Salen and Eric Zimmerman is also a must read for game design in general, might help you in how to translate an idea to game mechanics and such.

attachments.title: Mark Brown
attachments.text: How does Half Life teach without tutorials? Why didn't Capcom tell you that it was manipulating Resident Evil 4's difficulty? How are Nintendo's level design...

text: I do have the Art of Game Desigin, but I will get Rules of Play.
BY VFX I mean Particals and Effects

Cool, in regards to the particle and effects, that depends on learning the engines systems and using it in an appealing way. It's a mix of artistic and technical experience. 
I know Unity has a pretty decent particle system, that let's you change a lot of attributes to get the result you want. If you struggle with it, I would definitely just take time and explore it top to bottom, try different things, scour the net for tutorials. I wouldn't be afraid to make mistakes at this point since I'm just trying to learn the system, it's what I do with animation in fact.
In that sense you have to take the initiative Nana, if you know you struggle with something and want to improve on it, don't waste time and don't leave it for tomorrow (it's not easy, but that's where perseverance is key). One way to think of it is to do it in small focused chunks, take some time to just learn what each attribute does in the particle system, another day on applying your own art to it etc... 
Do it in a playful way, like you are exploring something, it takes the pressure off and makes it a ton more enjoyable :smiley: 
And please, show me what you make and study, I can provide you with feedback and help you improve!
